awd_titl_txt: Homeomorphism Groups of One-manifolds: Rigidity and Regularity
awd_abstract_narration:
One dimensional manifolds are fundamental objects in mathematics, and their structure and properties have attracted the attention of mathematicians for a long time. The focus of the project is the structure of the group of continuous symmetries of one-manifolds, including the local structure of the group of symmetries and the effect of smoothness on algebraic properties. The project will resolve several basic open questions about the structure of these groups and investigate new algebraic phenomena. The ideas and methods in the project will be broadly applicable to other fields, and will lie at the interface of topology, geometric group theory, and dynamical systems.

The structure of the homeomorphism groups of one-manifolds, especially compact one-manifolds, has received much attention over the years. Recently, this field has experienced tremendous development. The project will contribute to these advances by studying the local topology of the space of representations of a closed surface group into homeomorphisms of the circle, the local connectivity of which is a long standing open problem. Moreover, the project addresses the effect of regularity on the algebraic structure of finitely generated subgroups of homeomorphism groups on compact manifolds, and will construct groups which can act with prescribed levels of regularity but which are not smoothable to higher levels of regularity. The regularity of actions of Thompson's group F will also be addressed, with the goal of establishing the Brin-Sapir conjecture for smooth actions of F on compact manifolds.

por.por_cntn:
During the four years of this award, the PI carried out a number of research projects and completed several of the objectives outlined in the project description. These have included the construction of finitely generated groups with prescribed critical regularity, which provides discrete isomorphism invariants for diffeomorphism groups of the interval and of the circle. Moreover, the PI and his collaborators computed the exact critical regularity of many right-angled Artin groups and of all sufficiently complicated mapping class groups, showing that these are generally equal to 1. The PI is engaged in a continuation of this work, especially investigating the relationship between dynamics of group actions on one-manifolds and model theory, and generalizations of these ideas to dimension two and higher.

The PI carried out several other research programs, including a partial Margulis-type result, showing that under some relatively mild hypotheses, the commensurator of a thin normal subgroup of an arithmetic lattice has a discrete commensurator.

Among the broader impacts of this project is a book on the structure and regularity of group actions on one-manifolds, which was published as a volume of Springer Monographs in Mathematics in November 2021. This book will serve as a survey of and guide to the literature on critical regularity, and is usable as a first text on the subject for beginning to intermediate level mathematics graduate students.

While supported by this award, the PI served as an organizer and mentor in the University of Virginia's summer topology REU for two consecutive summers. This REU was specifically designed to make undergraduate research experiences available to underserved students from local institutions. The REU is slated to continue for the foreseeable future, and the PI plans to continue to take an active part in its organization.
